title: How to Setup Google Analytics 4 in Next.js
excerpt: Google Analytics 4 (GA4) is the latest version of the popular web analytics tool offered by Google. As the successor to Universal Analytics, GA4 comes with several new features and enhancements that provide businesses and marketers with more insights into...

text.content: Google Analytics 4 (GA4) is the latest version of the popular web analytics tool offered by Google. As the successor to Universal Analytics, GA4 comes with several new features and enhancements that provide businesses and marketers with more insights into their online presence. With GA4, you can analyze user behavior across multiple platforms, including mobile apps, websites, and other digital devices. In this article, we'll explore how to set up Google Analytics 4 in a Next.js app.

rich_text.plain_text: Google Analytics 4 (GA4) is the latest version of the popular web analytics tool offered by Google. As the successor to Universal Analytics, GA4 comes with several new features and enhancements that provide businesses and marketers with more insights into their online presence. With GA4, you can analyze user behavior across multiple platforms, including mobile apps, websites, and other digital devices. In this article, we'll explore how to set up Google Analytics 4 in a Next.js app.

text.content: Setup Google Analytics property, timezone and currency

rich_text.plain_text: Setup Google Analytics property, timezone and currency

text.content: Finish the submission form and accept the terms of service

rich_text.plain_text: Finish the submission form and accept the terms of service

text.content: Create a data stream by choosing the Web platform

rich_text.plain_text: Create a data stream by choosing the Web platform

text.content: Fill in the form and activate the Enhanced Measurement feature to collect basic events like page view, scroll, etc.

rich_text.plain_text: Fill in the form and activate the Enhanced Measurement feature to collect basic events like page view, scroll, etc.

text.content: After the data stream successfully created, you can see the instructions to install the gtag library into your site

rich_text.plain_text: After the data stream successfully created, you can see the instructions to install the gtag library into your site

text.content: Click “View tag instructions” then choose “Install manually”. Copy the code snippet and we will use it in our Next.js project

rich_text.plain_text: Click “View tag instructions” then choose “Install manually”. Copy the code snippet and we will use it in our Next.js project

text.content: Put the Google Analytics measurement ID from the previous instructions into environment variables via

rich_text.plain_text: Put the Google Analytics measurement ID from the previous instructions into environment variables via

text.content: and put the gtag script copied from the previous instructions.

rich_text.plain_text: and put the gtag script copied from the previous instructions.

text.content: Refresh your web app and make sure there are network requests to the Google Analytics endpoint

rich_text.plain_text: Refresh your web app and make sure there are network requests to the Google Analytics endpoint

text.content: Go to Reports → Realtime menu in the Google Analytics dashboard, then you’ll see new events are coming in

rich_text.plain_text: Go to Reports → Realtime menu in the Google Analytics dashboard, then you’ll see new events are coming in

text.content: In conclusion, setting up Google Analytics 4 in a Next.js app is a relatively straightforward process that can provide you with valuable insights into your website's traffic and user behavior. You can start analyzing user interactions and make data-driven decisions to improve your website's user experience and drive growth.

You can start analyzing user interactions and make data-driven decisions to improve your website's user experience and drive growth.
